text: pretend there's an intro here hi
everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review Japan droids celebration Rock
these guys are a rock duo from Canada
Vancouver specifically and this isn't a
sophomore LP the follow-up to the 2009
album post nothing and if you take a
listen to this album you are basically
going to find a bunch of teenage angst
and apathy anthems with blaring guitars
and drums that take as much away from
pop punk as they do indie rock and what
defines this album from track one to
track E is this exciting sense of just
youthful righteousness it's the stuff
memories from last summer are made of
fists being thrown into the air and rock
festivals where kids were coming of age
our crowd surfing and forming memories
that they may tell their kids about one
day you know Japan droids is really
great at conjuring imagery like this and
they do it with very bright distorted
guitars a lot of major scales and chords
this really punked out energy some very
relatable and in kind of poetic lyrics
that talk a lot about navigating life
and broken relationships and just the
the confusion of youth their lyrics that
embrace that apathy that I mentioned
earlier and acknowledge that yeah things
suck right now but kind of also see a
brighter future ahead because even
though this LP can be very negative at
points there are all these really hyped
up group chorus vocals screaming whoa
whoa xand oh yes and all rights that
on the flip side of things feel very
uplifting this is an album that really
sits down next to you puts an arm around
you and says man I know that feel oh man
do I know that feel I mean if this album
was put out in the late 90s early 2000s
it most likely would have been labeled
as emo
I think celebration Rock looks to strike
many of the same chords with its
listeners but manages to take all these
kind of angsty feelings and turns them
into a celebration like the title
suggests however my appreciation of this
album kinda stops there because
everything else on here musicianship
production songwriting variety every
other characteristic of this album to me
just isn't that fantastic I mean the
guitar sounds on this thing are kind of
plain even when they get kind of noisy
they still come off a little bland for
me on this album there's not an
interesting sound in sight from
beginning to end
and these guys write all their tunes in
a verse chorus verse structure for the
most part and when they head into the
second half of the song and repeat the
chorus and the verse again I don't
really feel like they change the song up
enough for me to kind of kick the
feeling of deja vu there's not really
anything new or memorable about the
melodies or the chord progressions on
here and the the OO chorus is really
just kind of bore me to be honest I
really like the energy that these guys
give off in their songs frontman Brian
King talks a really liberating game with
his explosive lyrics these guys
definitely come off with a we're gonna
give them hell kind of attitude I don't
doubt their sincerity and I don't think
anybody does which is why Japan droids
music resonates with so many people but
you know between the say me say me
melodies and the songs that could have
used more
detail in my opinion the predictable
chords and the okay production and the
kind of common sounds this album really
just leaves me underwhelmed I feel like
in terms of attitude and just aesthetic
this album would go over really well
like a bonfire where it's you and all
your friends on the night you graduated
high school
Japan droids are really great at making
music that really feels like the
soundtrack to a defining moment but
musically there's nothing really
definitive about what's going on here to
me like I said some okay music with some
really big feelings and that's pretty
much it I'm feeling really on the fence
with this album a strong five to a light
six really to be honest but what did you
guys think of this album did you love it
did you hate it why and what should I
review next anthony Fantana Japan droids
thank you for watching forever
[Music]
you
